C64.bio: The technical backbone of Dexion's C64 era. Matrix pioneered raster tricks, sprite multiplexing, and the custom interrupt routines that became group staples across dozens of releases.
Dexion's founding musician on the SID chip. Soundwave's distinctive arpeggios and driving basslines defined the group's audio identity throughout the C64 years and well into the Amiga era.
The longest-serving artist in the group. Pixel mastered character-set art and sprite design on C64 before transitioning to Amiga HAM and AGA modes, bridging both eras of Dexion history.
Founding member and organizer. Rambo maintained the group's contact network, coordinated disk-trading routes across Europe, and kept the crew motivated through the formative early years.
Joined to tackle 3D mathematics. Vector wrote the group's first vector engine for C64, opening the door to object demonstrations and scrolling polygon landscapes that wowed party crowds.

Amiga.bio: Dexion's Amiga lead coder from the very first release. Guru mastered the copper list, blitter, and custom chip set, producing the group's most technically acclaimed effects across every major production.
Prolific tracker musician responsible for the atmospheric soundtracks on most Amiga releases. Synth Master's modules were traded widely on bulletin boards and remain beloved across the scene.
The visual powerhouse of the Amiga section. Art Attack painted full-screen pictures, logos, and transitions that pushed the Amiga palette to its absolute limits on both OCS and AGA hardware.
Specialised in 3D engines and mathematical effects. Coder X wrote the texture mapper and particle system that powered several of the group's most celebrated final-era productions.
Co-author of Dexion Megademo 1. Mr. Mega Mind contributed scroll routines, part frameworks, and the fast loader system that was reused across multiple subsequent releases.
Brought a distinctly European electronic influence to the Amiga section. Future Freak's tracks layered complex polyrhythms with melodic hooks that were unusual for the era.
Early Amiga artist who designed the iconic Dexion logo seen in Megademo 1's intro screen. Tox retired from the scene in 1990 to pursue a career in commercial graphic design.
Part-coder on the first Megademo. Liteace specialised in audio replay routines and hardware-level interrupt management, ensuring perfect music synchronisation across hardware variants.
Finnish coder known for compact, highly optimised 68000 assembly routines. Pet contributed the copper plasma and smooth-scrolling effects in Megademo 1 before departing to work solo.
Transitioning seamlessly from C64 to Amiga, Pixel continued as the group's senior artist. His HAM-mode landscapes and chrome-mapped objects in Chrome Dimension were considered groundbreaking.
